Fields.DialogueText: Aye-aye, Captain!
Ammazza! Capitano, that was so inspiring!
Okay, everyone! Remember - the Morganas are always learning, but so are we. Keep it up and we'll stay ahead of them.
Stay sharp. Stay vigilant. And most of all... stay alive. Now, to your positions!
Thanks, Giorgio. I don't mean to be too strict, but I am the captain, after all.
I only wish I could deliver a rallying speech of such confident authority like that...

Fields.MenuText: Didn't we work on your public speaking skills already?
How long have you had stage fright for?

Fields.DialogueText: I managed to eke out an apology to the crew whilst clutching my dragon toy and staring into your eyes, Capitano. I'd like to give a passionate speech to just one person besides you.
Since as long as I can remember. I think it stems from my fear of being unable to move. "Locking eyes with someone" is a perfect metaphor for how trapped it makes me feel.

Fields.MenuText: It's nothing, really.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I do know a secret, covert trick to dealing with stage fright.
No, Capitano, it's so impressive! I'm truly jealous!
Really?
One that I employ every time I speak, in fact. Although... it's supposed to be a secret passed down captain to captain.
Normally I wouldn't ask you to break such an oath, Capitano. Yet... in light of the circumstances, perhaps you could bend the rules just this once?
Very well. After we dispatch these Morganas, meet me in my quarters and I'll whip you into shape in no time!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Okay, Giorgio. Are you prepared?
This is all very ominous, Capitano. Is the candle really necessary?
It's to help you lose yourself in the moment! Now, I want you to picture yourself standing on a wide stage.
D'accordo.
And in the audience, a crowd full of faces.
I may retract my previous statement...

Fields.MenuText: They're waiting to hear a speech. Anything will do.

Fields.DialogueText: I can talk about anything I want? That makes things even more difficult!

Fields.MenuText: They're in the mood for some light opera.

Fields.DialogueText: You want me to sing now?! I never claimed to be a singer, Capitano! I enjoy some Alberto Rabagliati now and again, but this is too much!

Fields.MenuText: They came for a dramatic reading.

Fields.DialogueText: The best I could do would be to read through the poems I've stored away in my room!
Now, let them have it!
I... I... I just can't do it, Capitano!
Hmm. I guess this is a lost cause.
You're giving up on me so easily, Capitano!?
What can I say? In showbiz, you've either got it or you don't.
Now, hang on a minute! I'm opening my eyes!
Just because I'm struggling doesn't mean I'm hopeless! Your language abilities were far from impressive, but I did my best to teach you!
This feels like nothing but sheer laziness on your part, Capitano! Frankly, I'm disappointed to see the kind of educator you turned out to be!
*GASP* Capitano?
Behind you, Giorgio.
Then this is...
Harold, Ma'am. The Captain enlisted my help in assisting you. Now that my role has been served, I'll take my leave, Captain.
That was a mighty powerful lecture you just administered to poor Harold there. You were looking straight into his eyes until the very end before you realized it wasn't me.
So... I'm cured?
All we have to do is make you incredibly angry and irritated any time you have to make a speech!
You tricked me! How embarrassing! If you ever deceive me like this again, you can rest assured I'll become angry in no time!
Luckily, Morganas make me ten times angrier than you ever could, Capitano! I'd like to use my newfound confidence to give them some stern words!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Capitano? Do you have a minute?
You're not going to scold me again, are you? I already apologized for tricking you.
No, no, nothing like that. Actually, I wanted to try something out on you. I remembered your advice about getting angry to speak publicly, but it's not in my nature to blow up at people like that.
So I thought I'd try writing poetry again and channel my negative emotions into my work. I thought combining the two would help.

Fields.MenuText: I'd love to hear it!
What kind of poem did you write?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not that well versed in the terminology, Capitano. I just wrote what was in my heart... and tried to make it rhyme.

Fields.MenuText: How long did you spend writing it?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm... I more so jotted down ideas whenever they came to me and eventually managed to rearrange them. A day or two perhaps?
Bene - but please don't expect too much. I asked for advice from the rest of the crew and they were really helpful, but I'm still not sure I could take everything they said on board.
Ahem...
*ALARM*
As if I don't have enough to worry about!
I'm on the edge of my seat! Let's deal with them quickly and return to your poem!
Well, we don't have to deal with them TOO quickly...
@BATTLE
Ahem!
The dragons' roars do so encroach. My homeland I will soon approach. Although the waves do crash and purr, Until that day, I will not stir.
My fear is known from shaking tibia, Though I press on, in aid of Libya.
That was beautiful, Giorgio. I could feel the heartache in every line - and it was a daring choice to do it in English.
Grazie, Capitano. You wouldn't believe how hard it is to find a word that rhymes with "Libya!"
Why don't you read it to the crew?
I could never! It's dreadful in its current state! And I could never throw my name into the ring so haphazardly. The crew are all master poets!
So no one but me will ever read your work?
At least let me work on it a little first...
Great! Whenever you're ready, let me know and I'll organize a perfomance night!
Still hard at work I see, Giorgio. I haven't seen you without a pen strapped to your hand in days!
Well, since you were so insistent I share a poem with the crew, I've been racking my brain for inspiration on what to write about.

Fields.MenuText: Where did the inspiration for your last poem come from?
What do you normally do to force inspiration?
Your first case of writer's block, huh?

Fields.DialogueText: I try to appear calm and placid in front of the crew, but there is always something bubbling below the surface. This war has no meaning, and it angers me that I alone am not strong enough to end it.
I am usually struck by the creativity bug halfway through a bath, where there is nary a pen or piece of paper in sight! Sometimes I feel as if someone just has it out for me...
It's a wonder how geniuses like Dante and Boccaccio ever managed to finish a scene! To create something from nothing takes so much talent!
Maybe it would do some good to get off the ship and stretch your legs.
D'accordo, Capitano. At the next port, I'll touch land with you.
Wonderful! Now, speaking of lovely views, it's a shame these Morganas had to ruin my open horizon.
This is worse than I thought. Your stress is reaching dangerous levels.
I have had my nose to this paper for a while now. None of these look like real words anymore. Is this a real word?
You're still doing this in English, huh? Anyway, yes... "numb." It's real.
Is it? What cruel and sadistic monster would place an unnecessary "b" on the end!?
A nice walk around a dock, or even standing next to some fragrant flowers, does sound intoxicating.
They say all forms of literature were originally designed to marvel at the wonders of nature. A nice view may be all you need.
M-O-R-G-A-N-A. That's a real word, right?
Why don't you switch your brain off for this one, Giorgio? Just let your guns do the talking!
@BATTLE
Ah, Capitano! You were right - this is just what I needed!
I know you can't stray too far from the ship, so it's lucky that this town lines its roads with flowers.
Their smell is delightful! The way it restores my strength, my drive... I'll get this boulder up the mountain yet!
I'll buy you a bouquet. It seems to be tradition at this point for me to buy you flowers whenever we dock.
They're lovely, Capitano. You spoil me.
Don't be silly. That's what friends are for!
I've never had someone care for me this much before.

Fields.MenuText: You've never had a friend?
What about your family?

Fields.DialogueText: Marco couldn't care less about my well-being. I'm convinced she sends me a postcard once a year just to clear her conscience for ignoring me the other 364 days.
Perhaps they were more like acquaintances. The Italian royals gave me gifts, but not out of concern for my mental health. They certainly never gave me flowers like this!

Fields.MenuText: I don't think this is anything special.

Fields.DialogueText: No, what have I been saying!? Even something small can do a world of good in the right circumstance. Maybe watching Snow White ten times together wasn't enough and you'd like to try for an eleventh.
It means a lot to me, Capitano. I won't soon forget it.
You may have to put it to the back of your mind for a while, Giorgio. Do you see what I see?
Morganas inbound! How dare they ruin such a touching moment!
@BATTLE
Giorgio? What are you doing in here?
Ah, Capitano! As thanks for helping me clear my head, I've decided to instigate a three-pronged payback mission to let you know how much I appreciate you!
Giorgio, you don't have to do all that. Like I said, that's what friends-- *mmph phurr*
No, non un'altra parola, Capitano. Don't even try and remove my finger from your lips. I do finger curls every day.
*mphh fmphh*
I understand that, but I'm doing this for me just as much as for you.
*mpphhggghh mphhhhh mphhhhh hphmmmmm phmmmmph*
Thank you very much for the compliment, Capitano, but I don't think this is the time nor the place to be so brazenly commenting on my appearance.
*Guh* I SAID, I won't stop you from doing what you want. I've learned that trying to make Giorgio sit still either physically or metaphorically is a futile endeavor.
Grazie, Capitano! Now then, for stage one. I just got off the radio and called in a favor for some new equipment!
The only catch is, the seller asked to use your name in conversation when selling his future wares. It seems buying the same products sold to one of your reputation makes them more reputable.

Fields.MenuText: Seeing as this is Giorgio's special present—how could I refuse?
I worry that should one of these products backfire, it's my name in the mud.

Fields.DialogueText: Great! I'll send a message now and it should arrive shortly!
Of course, Capitano. My apologies, I was so excited it didn't even cross my mind.
Moving on, seconda parte!
*ALARM*
You got me Morganas?! You shouldn't have! That's just what I always wanted!
After we deal with these miscreants, it's to the deck for you. I'll meet you there!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I'll need to vet him. Where do we keep finding these people?

Fields.DialogueText: They tend to come to me, Capitano. I don't mean to brag, but being a living saint has its advantages.
What's all this?
I know you said you would organize a presentation for me to recite my poem. But I wanted to do something for you, so I organized it myself!
Everyone agreed to turn up for your reading?
Not only mine, Capitano. It's going to be a lengthy performance by some of the crew's most literate artists! They all have poetry they'd like us to hear.
And I trust you will headline?
I suppose I'll have to.

Fields.MenuText: How did you do all this without me knowing?
Are you still nervous?

Fields.DialogueText: Onestamente, Capitano, it wasn't as difficult to keep you in the dark as you might have theorized.
Un poco, but I'll do my best to avoid eye contact with you.
Well then, bring on the festivities!
*SOME TIME LATER*
*APPLAUSE*
Grazie! Thank you all very much for your contributions so far. Both the Capitano and I have been moved by your poems. Now it is my turn.
Ahem...
*ALARM*
Morganas! Sorry, everyone, we'll have to cut this poetry reading short. Gear up for battle!
@BATTLE
It looks like no one is really in the mood for poetry anymore.
That's okay, Giorgio. It was a pleasant surprise to listen to several burly men recite beautiful literature.
I'm glad you enjoyed it. The finale will take place in your quarters! I'll see you there!

Fields.MenuText: I can hardly wait for part three of my gift!

Fields.DialogueText: Don't get ahead of yourself, Capitano! We still have yet to fully experience part two!
Ecco. I want you to have this.
Your dragon toy? Giorgio, I couldn't.
A causa tua, I don't need it anymore. It will always be special to me, seeing as it was a gift, but I know that it will be just as safe in your hands.
I don't know what to say...
Uh... Giorgio?
Sì, Capitano?
You have to actually let go of the toy if you want to give it to me.
Ah, si! Sorry about that...
Thank you, Giorgio. Rest assured, it will never leave my side.
Phew! This three-pronged reciprocation has taken it out of me!

Fields.MenuText: How long have you been planning this?

Fields.DialogueText: Not too long. I haven't been shirking my duties at all.

Fields.MenuText: Why go through all this trouble for me?

Fields.DialogueText: If you have to ask, Capitano, it seems I haven't done as good a job as I thought!

Fields.MenuText: Can I expect regular treatment like this from now on?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not a machine, Capitano! Well... not in this form at least.
*ALARM*
You might find a cleanly wrapped present under the tree come Christmastime. That is, if you haven't been a naughty Capitano all year round.
Did you bring any gifts for the Morganas?
If I had known they were coming, I would have picked up some coal!
By the looks of them, they'd probably end up liking it. We'd best send them straight to bed without supper!
@BATTLE
Capitano? Sorry to disturb you.
Can I help you with something, Giorgio?
No, it's fine! If you're busy, I can come back later!
I'm not particularly busy. What do you need?
Oh... it's just that I... fnshd... m... em.
What was that?
*Sigh* I finished my poem.
That's great news! Well then, don't let me stop--
But I'm still not ready to read it out loud yet! I thank the stars those Morganas interrupted us the other day. The poem I planned to read then was worthless compared to this.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I won't force you to read it.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll read it when I'm ready! By the way, Capitano, speaking of ready! Those Morganas look ready for battle, wouldn't you say! Let's get to it!
Giorgio, wait! Those ships are a good twenty minutes away!
@BATTLE
So, when can I expect to be graced by the reincarnation of Dante Alighieri?
I'll let you know. For now, best to just put it out of your mind. Grazie per il tuo tempo!
Since when was she so formal? That poem must be something else!

Fields.MenuText: How do I know that if I haven't heard it?
You can't hide your genius forever.

Fields.DialogueText: Some mysteries were not meant to be solved, Capitano. And speaking of mysteries... Dio mio, are those Morganas?
I... er, that is... those Morganas over there can't hide!
Capitano... can you smell something?
Nothing besides the fresh sea air.
I can definitely smell something...

Fields.MenuText: Something stuck in your nostril, Giorgio?
Which direction is it coming from?

Fields.DialogueText: How crude!

Fields.MenuText: It's not me, is it!? I showered twice today!

Fields.DialogueText: Straight ahead, I believe. So I know it isn't coming from the mess.
What does it smell like?
Desperation... perspiration... low expectation... mixed with a little raw fish.
Well, unless a salmon suddenly forgot how to swim, I don't know what to tell you.
Capitano, that's it! You're brilliant!
I am?
It's the scent of someone floundering amidst the waves, waiting to be rescued!
You can smell that from here?
I can hear it too! Listen!
"Please, someone help me! I'm drowning after being attacked by Morganas!" È perfettamente chiara!
What are you, some kind of bloodhound?
Battle stations, everyone! We're mounting yet another rescue. Look, Capitano, that seems to be one of the Morganas the wind told me about. It must have strayed off course.
Maybe it can lead us to the marooned crew! Giorgio, I'll never doubt you or that button nose again!
@BATTLE
No, Capitano, your scent is much different than this... NOT THAT I GO AROUND SMELLING YOU!
*WHOOSH*
These winds are harsh. They're slowing us down quite a lot. We'll get to the poor bugger, but he'll be mighty pruny by the time we do.
Just hold a little longer... puoi farcela...
You're doing better, Giorgio. You didn't fly into AS mad a panic as you did before when trying to rescue someone.
Don't get me wrong, Capitano. My insides are fit to burst with adrenaline right now. But I can at least compose myself enough to not endanger the lives of THIS crew by entering overdrive too early.
There's a few Morganas up ahead. Looks like we're following the breadcrumbs rather nicely.
Lascia fare a me, Capitano! I'm itching to get out there and let loose!
@BATTLE
There he is, Capitano! That flailing mass off the port bow!
Then it's the same as if I had the crew do it. You! Get that boy up on this ship as fast as possible!
He's unconscious, Captain! Administering first aid!
Capitano--!
Not! ... yet...
But--!

Fields.MenuText: Do you trust me?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course I do, but--!
Then trust in the men I employ as well.
He's awake, Captain! He looks like he's seen better days, but that's nothing a good meal won't fix!
Capitano! Thank goodness!
Whoa, Giorgio. There's no need for the impromptu hug, is there? I didn't do anything.
No, you're right. I trust you with my life, Capitano. Of course I can believe in those who you trust as well. It won't happen again.
Say no more about it. Now, come on, Twinkle Toes, I see you can barely stand still.
Si, Capitano!

Fields.MenuText: Down, Giorgio. You've done your part.
Save it for the dragons.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Right. But I can always do more...
It's not just dragons I'm sworn to fight, Capitano!
Let me closer, Capitano!
You can't just magic yourself over to him and grab him?
I can appear on my ship wherever I like... but I can't take someone with me!
*MINUTES LATER*
Get that food down you, lad. What did you say your name was?
Karl, Captain.
Karl, huh? Tell me how you found yourself marooned, Karl.
We were plain sailing, it looked like. Then we were ambushed.
Morganas?
Hundreds of them! In all directions!
Che strano. We rarely face more than a handful at any one time. To hear about a group of a hundred roaming the seas is quite frightening.
In any case, Captain. Would you allow me to come aboard your ship? I've got nowhere else to go and I can promise to work my darndest just so long as you keep on feeding me.
Hmm,  I suppose you can stay. I want to hear more about that Morgana fleet later, Karl, but for now, take your meal and make yourself scarce.
You won't regret this, Captain! People are always amazed by how surprisingly strong I am! After I've had a meal, that is! And thank you again, Lady Giorgio! Without your kindness--
Karl...
Yes, Captain? Oh! Right! Make myself scarce! Roger! I mean, aye-aye! I mean--
Karl!
Going!
Honestly... the people I keep aboard this ship just to make you happy.
I think he's kind of cute. Still... what he talked about was rather disturbing.

Fields.MenuText: A fleet of Morganas? Is that even possible?

Fields.DialogueText: It isn't IMpossible I suppose. I've certainly never witnessed it.

Fields.MenuText: Could the boy have been embellishing?
Maybe it was just a mirage.

Fields.DialogueText: A mirage that left him floating atop a plank of wood? That's some cabin fever if it's true.
Forse. He does seem kind of young. Still, it is worrisome.
*ALARM*
After this battle, let's adjourn to my quarters. I'd like to discuss this further.
@BATTLE
If what that boy said turns out to be true, what do you propose we do about it?
I wanted to say, Capitano... I think I'd like to fight that fleet.
Are you mad?! You can't take down a hundred-ship armada all by yourself!
But I won't be by myself, remember? I'll be with you.

Fields.MenuText: Doesn't it sound a little too dangerous?

Fields.DialogueText: Forse. Still, it's no more dangerous than the Libyan front I plan to protect.

Fields.MenuText: I'm no Belle. What help do you think I will be?

Fields.DialogueText: All I need is your cheering section, Capitano, to do my best.

Fields.MenuText: You believe in me that much?

Fields.DialogueText: Certo!
I've sworn to protect Libya with my life. Now the fated dragon set to destroy what I love has come into view. I can't sit idly by and let it wreak havoc.
That boy we've brought on board is cursed...
We couldn't just leave him to drown.
No... I just hope you don't make me regret bringing him on board.
You should trust the friends your friends trust, Capitano. Wasn't it you who told me that? He'll prove his worth eventually.
*ALARM*
That may be the case, but today isn't the day. It's not a hundred-strong armada, but it's enough for a warm-up. What do you say, Giorgio?
I'm right behind you!
@BATTLE
So, Giorgio. When am I going to hear this fabled final poem of yours?
Non ne sono sicura... The more I reread it, less inclined I am to share it.
You know, I've always found that teaching someone else is a good way to refresh one's thinking.
What are you saying, Capitano?
How about you teach me to write a poem? Hopefully it sparks the creativity you need to add the final touches to your work.
I'm not sure about that, Capitano. The last time you asked me to teach you something, things got awfully heated.
We've both grown a lot since then, don't you think? Matured like fine wine? What say we have another crack at it?
As long as you're sure...
First things first: let's give these Morganas a lesson they won't soon forget!
Si, Capitano!
@BATTLE
It's settled, then!
Although, as I've already stated, I'm not too familiar with poetic techniques...

Fields.MenuText: I'm not looking to win any awards. I want to write with emotion and passion! Like you do.

Fields.DialogueText: D'accordo. I'll do my best.

Fields.MenuText: Do you need to be? They all started as a feeling waiting to be expressed!
You'll get the hang of it. They're like any other weapon, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Si... si, I suppose that's true. Could it be that I'm writing tomorrow's rules for the form?
I don't know that I would talk about iambic pentameter like you'd talk about a lance, Capitano. It doesn't feel right.
JUST WRITE ABOUT WHAT YOU'RE FEELING! IS IT SO DIFFICULT TO...
Apologies, Capitano. I can-- I mean, YOU can do this.
I'll do my best...
Now... How. About. You. Tell. Me. What. You're. Feeling.

Fields.MenuText: I'm feeling happy. Like... a sunflower in the spring.
I'm feeling inexplicably and incandescently jovial!

Fields.DialogueText: Nobody likes a showoff, Capitano...
How poetic...

Fields.MenuText: I'm feeling a little scared, to be honest.

Fields.DialogueText: You have nothing to fear, Capitano. Just do as I say and nothing bad has to happen to you. D'accordo?
*ALARM*
Bene, Capitano. I think we've both earned a brief respite. Let's have a quick break and return afterwards!
I think I'd prefer the Morganas...
What was that, Capitano?
Nothing!
@BATTLE
Bene. Capitano, let's see what you've got.
It's a little embarrassing, but I decided to write about you, Giorgio.
Me?

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, I mean... you're pretty inspirational.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitano... I don't know what to say... I'm flattered.
Would you like me to read it for you?
Please.
Giorgio. You remind me of a couch...
Comfortable, soft, and supportive.
What do you think?
I think it's beautiful, Capitano. Well done.
*ALARM*
Just what I need after a lecture! Let's dispatch these Morganas quickly!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Maybe this way I can avoid another tongue-lashing...

Fields.DialogueText: I'll pretend I didn't hear that.

Fields.MenuText: You wrote about me before, so I'm returning the favor.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't bring up my earliest attempts, Capitano. I can't bring myself to recall them!
Giorgio, I've been thinking.
Capitano?
We'll need to bolster our offense to take down such a large fleet of Morganas.
Are you thinking of purchasing some new weaponry, Capitano?
Would it be of help to you?
Most definitely, but feel no need to put yourself out for my sake. Perhaps there is someone in this harbor town who knows of your exploits and would be willing to do service with you.
Actually, there is a retired officer turned salesman I'm acquainted with living in this town, I believe.
Shall we pay them a quick visit?
Sure! We're going to need all the help we can get!
Lead the way!
*SOME TIME LATER*
Niente affatto! What a lovely intermission this was, Capitano. Even if it's just a dock, it's nice to stretch my legs.

Fields.MenuText: Are you any more worried about the impending battle?
Maybe you can buy ME some flowers next time.
You don't stretch them enough fighting Morganas?

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes. Yet, when I think of the pleasant walk we'll take afterwards, it quells any angst I may have.
I'd be happy to! Just let me know your preferred taste!
I'm less of a kicker and more of a bombardier, Capitano.
I see some Morganas looking to dock. Let's deal with them and head back to the ship.
@BATTLE
I'm sorry to have wasted your time. I should've known he'd have already signed back up.
Giorgio. Have you noticed anything strange about that boy you brought on board?
He's a little talkative, but that's nothing out of the ordinary.
I just can't seem to put my finger on it. For some reason, he reminds me of you. Here he comes now.
*WALKING*
Afternoon, Captain! What lovely weather today! I wouldn't actually know, seeing as I've been attending to my duties all morning, but by the look on your face and Giorgio's, I can only assume-- WAH!
*POMPF*
That's what it is! He's suffering from the same bad luck virus as you were!
You may be right, Capitano. Even our initial meeting with him was surrounded by misfortune. His bad luck left him shipwrecked, but my good luck brought us to him.

Fields.MenuText: What should we do?
Do you think he can be cured?
Didn't I tell you that boy was cursed?

Fields.DialogueText: It's our responsibility to help him. If we aren't going to nurse the wounded bird back to full health after saving him, we should have left him as sustenance for the cat.
You managed to cure me, Capitano! Although it did take a lot; we've exhausted our supply of banana peels, for one!
Didn't I tell YOU that he will prove his worth eventually? Give him time.
Come over here, lad.
Right away, Captain!
Have you always been this unlucky, boy?
Oh yes, Captain. For as long as I can remember, I've been as deadly as a porcupine in a balloon factory.
Karl...
I think it dates back to my parents. Mother would always tell me that my bad luck was a lightning rod and my suffering was taking pain away from others. She would always--
KARL!
Yes, Captain!
Giorgio was suffering from similar symptoms and we managed to cure her. Come down to the engine room later today and we'll fix you right up.
Really, Captain? That would be excellent!
*ALAR--* I've always wanted to be able to enjoy life to the fullest. I hope that whatever methods you used on Giorgio can do just as much for...
Even the Morgana alarm can't get a word in edgeways...
@BATTLE
Here we are, Karl. Down in the guts.
Yes, Captain!
Giorgio's been having some engine trouble recently. It seems one of her marine cables has short-circuited.
The only problem is, I'm so darn sciocca, I forgot which wire I need to cut to relieve some of the pressure!
*Wink*
You need to cut a wire, Karl. Either the blue one or the red one.
One will allow me to proceed with less strain. But the other... will sink the ship!
What!? This is too much pressure for me, Captain. Surely you should--
Don't you disobey an order from your captain, lad. Now, do as instructed or you'll spend the night in the brig!
Let me fetch some scissors...
Cutting this wire isn't going to hurt you at all, right?
Relax, Capitano, they aren't even connected to anything. Whichever one he cuts will have no affect on ship functionality.

Fields.MenuText: This was a good plan, Giorgio. I never knew you were so devious.

Fields.DialogueText: What can I say? I learned from the best!

Fields.MenuText: Do you really think this will cure him?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe a placebo is all he needs. We can't all have Capitano's miracle elixir like I did to cure our pain.

Fields.MenuText: We might end up scarring him for life with this ruse.

Fields.DialogueText: Then we'll just have to cure that as well!
*ALARM*
Morganas!
We'll return after dealing with them! Make sure Karl is somewhere safe!
@BATTLE
OK, Karl. Whenever you're ready.
Giorgio... whatever happens, I want to thank you for rescuing me. Not many would have, but you saw something in me that no one else did. I'll repay you someday... either in this life or the next.
You can do it, Karl. I know I rescued you for a reason.
Here goes... NOTHING!
*Snip*
*REEEEEAK*
... Did it work?
Karl, you did it! I can feel the weight lifting off my shoulders!
I did it? I DID IT! I'M CURED!
Well done, lad, we're all mighty proud of you! Now, why don't you test that good luck out on those dirty latrines?
WITH PLEASURE!
Do you remember, Capitano, when you asked me why I strive so much to rescue people?
I vaguely remember saying something along those lines...
It's because every person has potential for growth. Every creature, big or small, could turn out to be a Karl. I can't risk even one heartbeat when I think about it like that.

Fields.MenuText: I understand, Giorgio.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad!

Fields.MenuText: Hopefully the next heartbeat isn't so chatty!

Fields.DialogueText: One can only dream!

Fields.MenuText: I never saw it that way before.

Fields.DialogueText: Even you, Capitano, have room to grow. Wouldn't it be disheartening to have your life cut short before reaching your full potential?
*ALARM*
If that boy's luck truly is real, these Morganas should be a cakewalk!
There's only one way to find out!
@BATTLE
Capitano. I think the time has come.
For what, Giorgio?
I would like to read you my poem.
Okay, shoot! I'm all ears!
Right here!? Right now!?
No time like the present!
I'd hoped to recite it somewhere more... private.

Fields.MenuText: Just what kind of poem have you written?

Fields.DialogueText: It's nothing like that! I know I've all but conquered my fear of public speaking, but I worry that has given birth to a new fear. Speaking in front of my capitano has never been so difficult!

Fields.MenuText: Where did you have in mind?

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps we could adjourn to your quarters after tonight's meal. Away from prying eyes...

Fields.MenuText: Is this the best one yet?

Fields.DialogueText: I'd like to think I improve with each new poem I write, so... I sincerely hope it is.
Very well. Come by my quarters later and I'll give it a listen.
Grazie for all your help so far, Capitano. My true home is on the battlefield. I didn't think I would ever be a poet.
*ALARM*
You are so much more than a Morgana killing machine, Giorgio. That being said, could you kill some Morganas for me?
Sempre, Capitano!
@BATTLE
No matter how often we do this, it's still so painfully embarrassing each time.
Come now, Giorgio. Does Shakespeare fear the sold-out show to his latest play? Does Disney fear the queue from America to Britain waiting to watch his most recent movie?
You're comparing my scribbles to genius again, Capitano...
If the shoe fits...
*Ahem* W-well, it c-can't be helped then! It is a direct order from my capitano, after all.

Fields.MenuText: What was your inspiration this time?

Fields.DialogueText: I found that trying to force inspiration to strike proved too much of a headache. I just wrote how I was feeling at the time.

Fields.MenuText: How long did this one take?

Fields.DialogueText: It's funny. Once I cleared my head and just allowed my hand to move, it didn't take too long at all.

Fields.MenuText: What is it about?

Fields.DialogueText: It's about my life on this ship, yet again. It seems I'm still only able to draw on personal experiences to influence my writing.
Ahem...
... Everything all right, Giorgio?
I was just waiting for the Morgana alarm. It has a habit of interrupting me during inopportune--
*ALARM*
Now, that's just plain rude...
I'll wait with bated breath for the finale to Giorgio's poetic saga! Let's deal with these Morganas quickly!
@BATTLE
Smiles fading into dust./With fire and brimstone comes mistrust./Laughter, joy, friendship./With pockets empty, my wealth overflows.
For those who bare their fangs at my spoils/Will not live to see tomorrow.
Wow... it didn't rhyme...
I thought I would try something a little different.
"With pockets empty, my wealth overflows." Do you really mean that?
I've grown so much under your command, Capitano. I feel richer than the richest man in the world.
After we return from battle, I'd like to hear that again if possible.
Sì, Capitano!
Ahem...
I think I can see the fleet in the distance, Capitano! I wonder if St. George felt a similar rush after laying eyes on the dragon for the first time.
It was no lie... that's easily a hundred Morganas, maybe more!
Don't go soft on me now, Capitano.
Relax, I'm just thinking of the type of poem I want written about the captain who took down a hundred-Morgana fleet.
I'll do my best to encapsulate your efforts here today, Capitano!

Fields.MenuText: Is it just me, or does that formation look distinctly like a dragon?
What do you think? A sonnet or a limerick?

Fields.DialogueText: They say that when two people become close enough, each starts to feel the other's pain. Such is the case. I apologize for the sorrowful future you may lead by my hands, Capitano.
There once was a fine Capitano./The greatest that I ever did know,/Though Morganas are strong,/And the battle was long,/They were no match for mighty San Giorgio!

Fields.MenuText: Do you think people will tell this story in a similar way to St. George's?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure, Capitano. Regardless, you can rely on me to spread the word as much as possible!
Well, on the subject of poetry... just looking at those clouds makes you realize why they invented pathetic fallacy. So dismal...
Pathetic what?
Pathetic fallacy: a literary technique where emotion is attributed to inanimate objects. Wait, aren't YOU supposed to be the poet?
Hahahaha!
Capitano! I hope we can spend more days comfortably laughing and making jokes like this!
Well, there's only one thing to be done. What say we casually take down a hundred-Morgana fleet!
These dragons will wreak havoc on my cherished land no more! To battle!
@BATTLE
Capitano! We're surrounded!
They just keep coming. Do you think we can hold out long enough to take them all out?
Don't worry about me, Capitano! I'm working up a sweat. I could do with a dash of--
*SHHHHHH*
Not only has your bad luck disintegrated, it's done a full 180 and turned into favorable fortune!
I'm not sure about that, Capitano. I only wanted a light drizzle, but this is torrential!

Fields.MenuText: We can't retreat anymore, you know?
What do you think St. George would do in this situation?
Are you not scared at all, Giorgio?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm terrified, Capitano! But to give in to the fear would be too damning!
St. George was far braver than I. He would have charged in headfirst to reap the spoils of battle. I couldn't do much without you standing beside me.
I never planned to! I'm in this for the long haul!
It'll be a difficult fight on such turbulent waters. This sudden storm has seen the waves pick up tremendously.
Don't worry, Capitano. I'll never let anything happen to you.
Nothing to it but to do it! Let's see how many we can take out before Davy Jones comes for us!
@BATTLE
*KSHHHHHHH*
We've made a nice dent, Giorgio! Can you keep going?
*sniff* Sì, il mio fantastico Capitano!
Who do you think you're talking to!?
That's the spirit! One final push!
Don't worry about me, Capitano! Just make sure you--
*KNGHHH*
Capitano! I've got you - don't let go! And don't look down either! There's nothing but a watery grave below you!
Giorgio... you can't bring me back with you, can you? Especially not when you've spent your strength in battle. Just... let me go...
Don't talk nonsense! Don't you know? A captain goes DOWN with their ship!
Capitano... if this is the end... I have to ask... Did you really enjoy my poem?
I've never been more moved by anything in my life! Now, I don't think I can hold on much longer. How's about we recite it to Poseidon together?
No, Capitano! Just... hold on!
*SPLOOSH*
... We're still alive? Giorgio, I'm sorry! I dropped your dragon toy in the drink after I let go. I promised to always keep it with me, but that promise... ended up being a death sentence.
It means the world to me that you kept it by your side, but I'm just happy you're alive! Capitano, there's a rope around you! Look up there! Someone must have lassoed you and is holding us both up!
What kind of inhuman monster could possess such strength?
I... told... you guys... I was surprisingly strong!
Karl!
Good on you, boy! Those meals in the mess have done you a world of good!
Your kindness saved my life once before and I always repay my debts! I'm going to pull you up now; just wait!
*SHHHHHHH*
*GLOMPF*
Good job, lad! Now, let's finish off the last of these brutes!
@BATTLE
*KAW KAW*
It looks like the rain has subsided.
Karl. Consider your life debt repaid. You will forever be a member of this crew. Go down and check that everyone's all right for me, would you? I need a moment with Giorgio.
Yes, Captain!
Giorgio... your kindness, compassion, and empathy are a gift. By following your heart, you saved both of our lives tonight. I'm proud to be your best friend.
C-*sniff* C-*hic* Capitano... You're *hic* the best friend anyone could ever have!
Now... can I hear that poem one more time?
KYA! Capitano!
*SPLASH*
No! Capitano, if I lose my best friend, this battle is as good as lost!
